title: Keep an eye out for these 13 suspicious “don’t get vaccinated” narratives
subtitle: IORG Dokidoki Alert Weekly ﹋ No. 7 ﹏ 2021.7.12-18

What’s Up Last Week?

In this Weekly, IORG presents 13 suspicious or false narratives telling people “don’t get vaccinated”. Stay alert.

Listed below are suspicious narratives about “don’t get vaccinated” and some have been proven false. Narrative content might cause negative impact towards personal and public health. Please practice extra caution.

On July 7th, COVID-19 death toll reached 4 million worldwide. WHO Director-General said that in order to control the pandemic, designing a “global vaccination plan” is urgent. He also mentioned in the 138th meeting of the International Olympic Committee that the common goal must be to vaccinate 70% of the population of every country by the middle of next year to end the pandemic and reboot the global economy.

Last week, “reservation for vaccination” was the most popular topic among Facebook chinese posts and Taiwanese media reports. At the same time, as many as 13 suspicious narratives encouraging the public, explicitly or implicitly, “don’t to get vaccinated” appeared in the Taiwanese information sphere. Among them, 4 have been proven false. According to IORG’s database, between July 12th and 18th, there are at least 4,50 LINE messages containing the word “vaccines”. And there are at least 32 messages, which come from different 14 groups, spreading in total 13 suspicious narratives on “don’t get vaccinated”. IORG put these suspicious narratives into 3 categories based on their “degree of discouragement”: “Worse if vaccinated”, “Don’t get vaccinated”, and “No need to get vaccinated”.

In addition, IORG found some of these narratives will combine together in a single message, possibly making the message more compelling. Compared to the conspiracy theory “vaccines are biochemical weapons” in volume 3, the 13 suspicious narratives observed in this volume offer more details, making them more convincing.  

These 13 suspicious narratives have 2 features. The first feature is that most of them “appeal to authority”. Among them only 2 narratives cite unverified information as their source, and the other 11 all refer to the statements made by authorities such as doctors, immunologists, and medical personnels. Having the endorsement of “authorities” will make information receivers easier to believe in these narratives, despite the fact that the information itself might be manipulated. Another way to enhance the credibility of these narratives is to attach videos to the messages. 8 of these 13 suspicious narratives have videos attached to them, and 5 use the videos from a website called “Rumble”.

About “appeal to authority”

“Appeal to authority” isn’t necessarily a bad thing, unless the “authority” that a message refers to is not a real or pertinent expert in the field, or the message twists the statement made by the authority. In that case, we can say the message “inappropriately appeal to authority”, making it an information manipulation.

About “Rumble”

Rumble is a Canadian video sharing website created in 2013. According to Wikipedia, Rumble's monthly user count has experienced rapid growth since July 2020, from 1.6 million monthly users to 31.9 million by the end of the first quarter of 2021. Former US president Donald Trump officially joined Rumble on June 26, 2021.

The second feature of these narratives is that they often incite emotions like fear and distrust. Among them, 5 contain content that might provoke fear, saying that vaccines “will cause cancer”, “modify genes”, and “reduce lifespan.” Another 5 might induce readers' distrust towards the media and the government by saying that “the media didn’t report at all”, “the government recommends vaccines that kill people.” There are also 4 narratives that claim they are providing “the truth”, implying that readers have been fooled and making them question the societal consensus that “vaccination is beneficial in fighting the pandemic.”
